Award.AwardTitle: Studio STEM: Engaging Middle School Students in Networked Science and Engineering Projects

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Studio STEM employs active, inquiry-based learning through engineering design activities to promote conceptual change and problem solving techniques using information and communications technology (ICT). The project aims to engage and encourage rural Appalachian middle grade students to pursue STEM using fundamental concepts in energy conservation and sustainability through an informal design-based studio. This setting allows students to creatively explore and share problems and solutions by documenting their experiences using personal blogs. The project builds on a previously piloted interdisciplinary curriculum, Save the Animals, developed in partnership with the Virginia Middle School Engineering Education initiative and focuses on solving energy-related problems that explore relevant environmental issues affecting animals and humans.

For this project, four curriculum modules are presented and grouped in themes by year. Students explore and design around energy transfer in Save the Penguins (energy efficient dwellings), alternative energy generation in Save the Fish (hydroelectric dams) and Save the Bats (wind turbines), and alternative transportation in Save the Seagulls (solar cars). All modules incorporate the 5-E learning cycle (engage, explore, explain, elaborate, and evaluate).

Student participants interact with selected undergraduate volunteers from the College of Engineering at Virginia Tech, and industry/community partners. At completion, Studio STEM will have served over 300 students in grades 6-8 and trained over 200 middle school teachers and undergraduate volunteers to implement the design-based curriculum through a series of professional development workshops. External evaluation consists of both formative (using a mixed methods approach) and summative assessment, utilizing online surveys, observations, and focus groups designed specifically for the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Studio STEM was a three-year NSF ITEST project that offered middle school youth from an impoverished, rural area, the opportunity to engage in meaningful engineering design activities that helped them understand and learn to mitigate the impact that certain technologies have on the environment. Sessions occurred throughout the school year and over the summer. The youth were mentored by local university student facilitators and local high school students, and they engaged in digital dialogue with each other, their facilitators, and their teachers through the Social Networking Forum, Edmodo, which promoted collaboration and design thinking. They designed solutions to environmental problems affecting animals, and learned significant science content. They were visited by local industrial partners, and engaged in field trips to local industries and science museums. Youth who participated in this project made significant gains in several key areas. Some youth became more motivated to pursue STEM careers. In addition, some youth became more skilled at problem solving and developed more confidence to solve problems. Youth also found their Studio STEM experience to be motivating in that: they felt empowered to make choices, they found the activities useful, they felt successful, they felt cared for by the mentors and other adults, and they were more interested in science as time went on than peers who did not participate in the project.

The project researchers were able to investigate critical factors affecting motivation, science learning, and engineering design abilities. Each year, they modified the curriculum slightly to investigate better ways to engage youth in informal settings. They were also able to investigate best practices for the mentors who worked with the youth and develop a guide to assist them in questioning strategies and facilitation strategies. Researchers were able to look at the tinkering gap that existed between boys and girls in the project, and posit ways to mediate this gap. They were able to create media-rich iBooks about the curriculum so that teachers across the country could implement it easier and with more fidelity.

Studio STEM is serving as a model for partnerships between higher education institutions, rural schools, science museums and centers, and businesses. This model can be adopted to address local educational, professional development, and workforce needs. As a result of Studio STEM, students, teachers, site leaders, facilitators and community partners have increased access to a broad selection of online tools, materials, strategies, and activities. Project researchers are developing a better understanding of the types of science and engineering instruction that are motivating to students in out-of-school settings.

Colleagues may be interested in using similar methodologies that we have used to promote students’ motivation, through the synergy of using college and high school students as mentors, using curricular materials that promote the “helping aspect” of engineering, and through Social Networking Forums. They may also be interested in using the MUSIC Model of Academic Motivation Inventory because, through this project, we have provided more validity evidence for its use with upper-elementary and middle school students. Colleagues may be interested in downloading the four iBooks which contain the curriculum materials, to consider using the Save the Animals curricula with youth in either formal or informal settings. Our work integrating Edmodo into the experience should be of great interest to colleagues who want to use technology in a meaningful way to create socially constructivist environments that reach today’s digital natives.

To learn more about Studio STEM, visit us on our homepage: http://studiostem.fincsu.wpengine....
